did.abstract: Environmental education teacher at East Grand Rapids, Michigan, High School and member of the board of the West Michigan Environmental Action Council. Subject files consisting of newsletters, reports, testimonies, and printed material relating to Michigan environmental issues.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The papers were donated by William M. Cary (donor no. 7474) in August 1987.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., William M. Cary Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: William M. Cary is a biology teacher at East Grand Rapids High School and an active member of the Michigan Environmental Education Association. As such, Cary has worked for the incorporation of environmental education programs in Kent Intermediate School District. From 1972-1974 Cary and colleagues developed and implemented plans for a nature walk: the Manhattan Nature Trail in Hodenpyl Woods, Grand Rapids. Cary has collected materials on a variety of environmental issues of particular interest to Michigan environmentalists, as well as printed materials of two Grand Rapids-based environmental organizations, the West Michigan Environmental Action Council, and the Center for Environmental Studies.

scopecontent.p: The William M. Cary papers consists of three-quarters linear foot of newsletters, reports, testimonies, and printed materials concerning Michigan environmental issues and groups. The collection is arranged alphabetically in one topical series. There are nine subseries, including: Center for Environmental Study, Energy Conservation, Environmental Education, Manhattan nature Trail, Noise Pollution, Nuclear Power Plants, Pesticides, Water Quality, and West Michigan Environmental Action Council, covering the years 1963-1986. The three subseries of primary interest to researchers are Environmental Education, Manhattan Nature Trail, and Water Quality as they are the most complete.

did.unittitle: Center for Environmental Study (printed material), 1971 and undated
